Junod (1962b: 23) says tilled & planted in lines carefully
hoe
Junod (1962a: 62) specifically says no protection of fields from the goats
in some tribes the men own their own plots which they seed but do not weed or harvest. But usually the woman does all.
for no man may plant before the chiefs; [cf. 4th edition trait #18]
given to king – make beer – entertain
goats, oxen

the average village probably does not exceed 60 but the capitol & others may have over 100 members [cf. 4th edition trait #31]
have wall of thorns but this not for protection in war
dung & mud
circular
need thatching every 3 or 4 years - & mud probably repaired even more often
mud & dung over basket work
clay
Lands reverts to chief in the end since all his property – however land is inherited
use natural marks (Junod 1962b: 6); dig a 1 foot deep ditch around gardens (Junod 1962b: 9); [cf. 4th edition trait #14]

only perishable things buried with dead
in the presence of witnesses; [cf. 4th edition trait #87]

to till chiefs field, clean his compound etc.

certain portion of the harvest
a basket of mealies from each village at harvest time
royal marriages [underlined]
man who keeps the sacred forest – cemetery of royal family, appointed & paid by chief; all land is chief’s
six clans with different dialects; Royal family; age grades (Junod 1962a: 13); The hunters considered superior class (Junod 1962b: 59)
royal [underlined]; [cf. 4th edition trait #125]
royal genealogies 8-10 generations
alliances between clans
man gives child his name & then they have special relationship – godfather
payment of cattle.
Bride brings utensils etc. (Junod 1962a: 112); must work & cook for the groom’s mother for 1 year (Junod 1962a: 125)
The well off have much prestige
royal family, chiefs
only chief can sit on something above the ground
The chiefs & their favorites will have the best – but anyone can have as much land as they can use
Only 6 or 7; (Junod 1962a: 287) - picture of some chief’s wives around 22 – so there must have been others with as many or nearly that number
only old men of noble rank get the wax crown in the capitol – others crowned with less ceremony in own villages
chief has a music contest
elaborate vault grave – split level, with little house on top
women become property of their captors & can be sold; [cf. 4th edition trait #121]
as wives
[cf. 4th edition trait #123]
village with chief, district with chief, king
[cf. 4th edition trait #145]
village
in order to get land in new area must ask district chief who is in charge of it all
chief
tries adulterer
watched over by counsellors & taught to play chief with playmates (Junod 1962a: 369); made subchief (Junod 1962a: 410)
counsellor in charge of each village (Junod 1962a: 196); Hosana chief of subclan or district (Junod 1962a: 357)
council of headman presided over by chief
counsellors
one man goes to village blowing horn – gives it another who goes to next village etc.
appoints subchiefs for the districts
case in which victim of theft goes to complain to chief; [cf. 4th edition trait #168]
chief repays visits to his subjects at the end of harvest season
whenever he travels he takes along all his wives
only the true chief can order construction of the circumcision lodge (Junod 1962a: 94); first fruits (Junod 1962a: 397)
depends on clan – copper bracelet, sacred tusk
crawl on hands on hands & knees
some sort of oath of allegiance
each clan, each person has a string of “laudatory names, but the chief has many more
not safe to touch him or mention his name
only by his own family. He turns into a wild animal (Junod 1962a: 448); royal family becomes special set of gods – invoked in circumstances relevant to the whole country (Junod 1962b: 374)
people must pay for queen’s bride price
chief keeps wives in every district.; All land is the property of the ruler
Herald who wakes chief up each morning by praising his royal heretage & disparaging the chiefs own abilities.; [cf. 4th edition trait #170]
gathers his favorites around him
if king has 40 or more – subjects probably do not have more than 15-20
one chief so jealous that locked his wives up in their villages & put a guard over them
[cf. 4th edition trait #173]
(+); teachers watch over the prince – but he must not reside in capital until he’s older
in case of suspected sorcery
village headman settles disputes by mediation
magistrates in each district appointed by chief
mention the chiefs executioners
sorcery punished by fine, banishment
adultery considered theft of wife & social infringement (Junod 1962a: 197); if sold a sick cow must be given another (Junod 1962a: 439)
refusing to abide by courts decision
adultery (Junod 1962a: 196); divorce (Junod 1962a: 439)
insults
punished by gods
adultery paid by fine & a hoe for the counselor.
if headman considers a villager to be damaging to village property through drinking etc. he can confiscate their money
headman the offended party because all property his
children who have transgressed are trashed by chief
death penalty for murder
Thief punished by gods – but I think only if he won’t confess
the induna
commanders [underlined]
take it a coronation of chief
companies make up a botshu which make up a battalions. 9 battalions.
straight line, or circle

each regiment has different costume of special animal
parts taken to make medicines
cattle & women
only women

(+); when whole army cowardly chief made them carry pots like women on hands & knees
make prayers to gods of conquered people because they were the first to own the land & they might get angry at conquerors

family gods
pregnant women who die, suicides etc. become spirits of bitterness

(-); no mention but apparently thank offerings are few.
ceremony of erecting new village
go to royal burial forest – or to capital

each village has its sacred tree at the foot of which sacrifices are carried out (Junod 1962a: 313); sacred wood where chiefs buried (Junod 1962b: 378)
many concoctions made & burned to be inhaled
shamans [underlined]
The keeper of the sacred chief pellets if given house, wife & cattle by chief. Chiefs head shaman.
